chapter.title: Description of raw images
chapter.para: &slema; raw images are delivered for the x86_64 architecture (an image with RT kernel is available), IBM ZSeries (an image of the KVM host, images to be used with FBA or DASD devices) and also AArch64. These images are intended to be configured on the first boot by using either Ignition or Combustion. The boot loader detects the first boot, see more in . Each image has default mounted subvolumes as described in . The procedure of deploying these images is described in .

sect1.title: Default partitioning
sect1.para:
The raw images are delivered with a default partitioning scheme, which can be changed during the first boot by using Ignition or Combustion. For a procedure of repartitiong the system, refer to
or .

important.title: Btrfs is mandatory for the root file system.
important.para: Bear in mind that if you intend to perform any changes to the default partitioning scheme, the root file system must be btrfs.

sect1.para: Each image has the following subvolumes:
The images also have mounted subvolumes for booting by default. The concrete subvolumes differ according to the architecture.
You can recognize the subvolumes mounted by default by the option x-initrd.mount in /etc/fstab. Other subvolumes or partitions must be configured either by Ignition or Combustion.

sect1.title: First boot detection
sect1.para: The configuration runs on the first boot only. To distinquish between the first and subsequent boots, the flag file —/boot/firstboot_happened is created after the first boot took place. If the file is not present in the file system, the attribute ignition.firstboot is passed to the kernel command line, which triggeres creating initramfs with Ignition or running the dracut module in case of Combustion. After completing the first boot, the /boot/firstboot_happened flag file is created.

note.title: The flag file is always created
note.para: Even though the configuration may not be successfull, due to improper or missing configuration files, the /boot/firstboot_happened flag file is created.
You may force the first boot configuration on subsequent boot by passing the ignition.firstboot attribute to the kernel command line or by deleting the /boot/firstboot_happened flag file.
